clinical_study.brief_title: Preventing Sexual Violence in College Men: RealConsent for Use in Vietnam
clinical_study.official_title: Preventing Sexual Violence in College Men: Adaptation and Impact Evaluation of RealConsent for Use in Vietnam

collaborator.agency: Center for Creative Initiatives in Health and Population

brief_summary.textblock: This study is a randomized controlled trial using a web-based adaptation of the RealConsent program among 400 eligible college men in Hanoi, Vietnam. This study will test the impact of the program on promoting prosocial bystander behavior and preventing sexual violence perpetration, through improvements in the seven knowledge, attitudinal, and emotional mediators over a seven month study period, with a baseline survey and two follow-up surveys.

detailed_description.textblock:
Sexual violence is any sexual act committed against a person without freely given consent. Men and women may experience sexual violence, but most victims are women. Women's first experiences of sexual violence often occur in adolescence. In Asia and the Pacific, about 14% of sexually experienced adolescent girls report forced sexual debut. Thus, early prevention with men is critical; yet, young men often are difficult to reach and may resist programs that target sexual violence, not seeing themselves as potential perpetrators. Prevention with men that integrates a bystander framework, which treats men as "allies" of women, is one way to target attitudes and behaviors while decreasing resistance to participation. In this study, the researchers will adapt an existing program for use with men attending one of two universities in Hanoi, Vietnam. This study will test the impact of the adapted program on knowledge/attitudinal/emotional mediators, and in turn, on sexual violence perpetration and prosocial bystander behavior in this target group. The adapted program is a novel, six-session, web-based serial drama and educational program designed to prevent sexual violence perpetration and to enhance prosocial bystander behavior in young men. The program has reduced the incidence of sexual violence among men attending an urban, public university in the Southeastern United States.
After conducting interviews with men and women, and focus group discussions with college men and university stakeholders the researchers will produce a web-based adaptation of the RealConsent program in Vietnam. The researchers will then conduct a randomized controlled trial to test the impact of the adapted program (200 participants), relative to a health-education control condition (200 participants), on knowledge/attitudinal/emotional mediators, and in turn, on sexually violent behaviors, and prosocial bystander behavior in freshmen men attending two universities in Hanoi. This project will be the first to adapt and to test the impact of a novel, theoretically grounded, web-based intervention to prevent sexual violence perpetration and to promote prosocial bystander behavior among young men for use in a middle-income country. If this study shows that the adapted program is effective cross-culturally, it will have exceptional potential for scale-up to prevent men's perpetration of sexual violence against women globally.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Responses to Situations Score
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Posttest (immediately after completing the intervention), 6 Months after intervention
primary_outcome.description: Bystander self-efficacy to intervene when witnessing sexual violence will be assessed with a 15-item survey asking how much they agree with different scenarios of violence. Responses are given on a 5-point scale where 1 = totally agree and 5 = totally disagree. Total scores range from 15 to 75 with higher scores indicating greater self-efficacy for intervening when witnessing situations of sexual violence.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Readiness to Intervene Score
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Posttest (immediately after completing the intervention), 6 Months after intervention
primary_outcome.description: The readiness of participants to intervene when witnessing acts of sexual violence is assessed with 19 items where respondents rate how confident they are to intervene on a scale of 0 to 2 where 0 = not confident at all and 2 = very confident. Total scores range from 0 to 38 and higher scores indicate greater confidence with intervening.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Posttest (immediately after completing the intervention), 6 Months after intervention
primary_outcome.description: Participants are asked about strategies they have used to intervene when witnessing sexual violence with 17 items describing behaviors they may have witnessed in the past 12 months. Items are scored as 0 = never performed, 1 = performed once, 2 = performed more than once, and with an option to indicate they have not witnessed that particular event. For participants witnessing every event, scores range from 0 to 34 with higher scores indicating increased behaviors to intervene when witnessing sexual violence.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Posttest (immediately after completing the intervention), 6 Months after intervention
primary_outcome.description: Experiences with sexual violence will be assessed with a survey asking respondents how frequently they engaged in acts of sexual violence in the past 6 months.The 45 items are scored on a scale from 1 to 4 where 1 = 0 times and 4 = 3 or more times. Total scores range from 45 to 180 with higher scores indicating more frequent use of force or coercion to engage in acts of sexual violence.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Knowledge of Legal Definitions of Assault and Rape Scale Score
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Posttest (immediately after completing the intervention), 6 Months after intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Knowledge of the law will be assessed with 21 items where respondents indicate if they think the situations described are illegal (scored as 1), legal, but harmful (2),or not sexual violence (3). Total scores range from 21 to 63 with higher scores indicating less awareness of laws related to sexual violence.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Knowledge of Informed Consent to Have Sex Score
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Posttest (immediately after completing the intervention), 6 Months after intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Knowledge of sexual consent will be assessed with 15 items where respondents indicate how much they agree with each statement on a scale of 1 to 5, where 1 = totally agree and 5 = totally disagree. Total scores range from 15 to 75 where higher scores indicate less knowledge about sexual consent.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Posttest (immediately after completing the intervention), 6 Months after intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Attitudes regarding gender roles will be assessed with a 15-item survey asking participants how much they agree with statements about stereotypical gender roles. Responses are given on a 5-point scale where 1 = totally agree and 5 = totally disagree. Total scores range from 15 to 75 and lower scores indicate greater alignment with stereotypical gender roles.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Myths and Realities about Sexual Violence Score
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Posttest (immediately after completing the intervention), 6 Months after intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Beliefs about what other men think about myths and realities of sexual violence is assessed with 24 items asking respondents to indicate how much they agree with each statement. Responses are given on a scale from 1 to 5 where 1 = totally agree and 5 = totally disagree. Total scores range from 24 to 120 with lower scores indicating that the respondent thinks men his age agree more with myths concerning sexual violence.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Posttest (immediately after completing the intervention), 6 Months after intervention
secondary_outcome.description: A19-item instrument will be used to assess what participants consider as behaviors of sexual coercion. Responses are given as 0 = no, 1 = yes, and 2 = unsure. More responses of "yes" indicate a greater understanding of behaviors that are sexually coercive.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Sexual Violence Myths Score
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Posttest (immediately after completing the intervention), 6 Months after intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Rape attitudes will be assessed with 24 items presenting scenarios of rape. Items are scored on a scale from 1 to 5 where1 = totally agree and 5 = totally disagree. Total scores range from 24 to 120 and higher scores indicate greater understanding of rape-myth.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Alcohol and Consent Score
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Posttest (immediately after completing the intervention), 6 Months after intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Beliefs about consent in terms of alcohol use are assessed with 10 items where respondents indicate how much they agree with each statement. Responses are on a scale from 1 = totally agree to 5 = totally disagree. Total scores range from 10 to 50 where lower scores indicate less understanding of sexual consent under the influence of alcohol.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Posttest (immediately after completing the intervention), 6 Months after intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Empathy for rape victims will be assessed with a modified version of the Rape Empathy Scale (RES). This assessment includes 17 items where respondents select the statement that is most true for them from two options. Responses are scored as 1 or 2 and total scores range from 17 to 34 where lower scores indicate less empathy towards rape victims.

arm_group.description: Participants randomized to this study arm will receive adapted program of RealConsent.
Participants in the control arm will receive a web-based health promotion program.

intervention.description: The program is a novel, theory-driven, evidence-based serial drama and educational program tailored to young men and delivered in six episodes via the web. Participants will view 6 30-minute modules designed to prevent sexual violence in young men
Participants will view 6 30-minute web-based serial drama modules designed to promote health.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Identifying as heterosexual or bisexual
- Enrolled as a freshman at Hanoi Medical University or Thang Long University on 9/1/2019
Exclusion Criteria:
- None

patient_data.ipd_description: All de-identified data will be available for sharing, including data dictionaries, with the exception of potentially sensitive items on sexual violence perpetration.
patient_data.ipd_time_frame: Data will be made available for sharing beginning 12 months after the end of the study, with no end date.
patient_data.ipd_access_criteria: Data are available for sharing with researchers requesting data from the Principal Investigator and study steam, providing the analysis plan and study aims are approved. Data will be shared via a secure link through Emory Box as STATA, Excel, and SAS files.
